summary.seg: This manuscript, completed in 1652, contains Biblical commentary, theological notes on a variety of verses from different books of the Old and New Testaments. The cited texts are written in the original Greek or Hebrew, while some of the commentary passages are in Greek and others in Latin. Peculiarly, after filling the first 41 folios of the manuscript, the writer began writing from the opposite end of what was presumably a bound note book, eventually filling it and meeting the end of the text written previously (f. 41v), and adding a colophon remarking on this convergence. The meeting of these two sequences of text on a single page, as well with the consistent placement of the watermarks, indicates that this peculiar arrangement was not the result of quires being bound erroneously.
A note on f. [iv] verso suggests that the text may be the work of Adam Littleton

msItem.title: Biblical commentary
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ρωμ. ηʹ αʹ τοῖς μὴ κατὰ σάρκα περιπατοῦσιν, ἀλλὰ κατὰ πνεῦμα Τοῦτο χαρακτηριστικόν τῶν έν Χριστῶ παραμυθίων ἡμῖν, ὅταν τυρβάζομεν
msItem.explicit: f. 41v ἀλλ'οὐκ ἐν τῆ τοῦ λόγου οἰκονομία, ἥτις οὐχ ἥτις ἐστι θεῖον δικαίωμα

support.material: Western paper, folded in octavo. Watermark: Pot ( c. 68 c. 35 ) at the lower end of the gutter, comparable but not identical to Heawood 3624, 3626. These examples are dated to 1652-57.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [i-iv] + 1-41, 87-42 + [v-vi], in pencil, in Arabic numerals. On ff. 1-41 the folio numbers appear recto in the upper right-hand corner. The text on ff. 42-87 proceeds inwards from the right-hand end of the book, and is therefore inverted. These folios are foliated in accordance with their order in the textual sequence rather than their placement in the manuscript. The position and orientation of the folio numbers is also determined by the sequence of the text rather than the physical arrangement of the manuscript; they therefore appear on the verso, on ff. 87-57 in the actual lower left (upper right in relation to the text), and on ff. 56-42 in the actual lower right (upper left in relation to the text).

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 11 quires, of which three are ternia, two are quinia and the rest are quaternia.

list.item:
Quire 58+1 ff. 33-41
f. 41 appears to be adhered to this quire

supportDesc.condition: The outer half of the original flyleaf f. iv has been torn away, and the paper of the leaf is soft. f. 42is largely detached. The sewing structure is fragile. The binding closes poorly. There is water and mould staining, and areas of dirt.

handNote.p: The Greek text was written in early modern western European mixed minuscule script, in brown ink.

additions.p: A dated note, in the same hand as the main text, appears on f. 1r: October 19 1651 ρχῇ ἦν ὁ Λόγος There are occasional marginal annotations and pen-trials by the same hand.
There is a damaged note on f. [iv] verso: Ad. Littleton , which may be the name Adam Littleton.

binding.p: 17th-century binding with paper covering over millboards, with plain pastedowns. The classmark is tooled in gold on the spine.

history.origin: The manuscript was completed on 30 May 1652, as indicated by the colophon on f. 41v. The note on f. 1r giving the date 19 October 1651 may indicate the date when it was begun. It may have been the work of the cleric and teacher Adam Littleton (1627-1694) Littleton, Adam, 1627-1694 , as suggested by the note on f. [iv] verso. At the time of the manuscript's production, Littleton was studying at Oxford University, from which he had been expelled for dissent against the Parliamentarian authorities in 1648, but subsequently reinstated.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: A catalogue of the manuscripts preserved in the library of the University of Cambridge
